title: The application of precision agricultural techniques to archaeological survey

tasks.task: Operate drones equipped with infrared cameras for archaeological survey
subtasks: Plan the flight altitude for drones (75 meters)
Choose the appropriate NDVI index for image processing
Capture near infrared and visible light images to create NDVI maps
Analyze land cover changes using historical and aerial photographs
Identify archaeological remains such as Roman roads and structures through NDVI anomalies

tasks.task: Survey specific zones with known or possible Roman road locations
subtasks: Verify control samples in areas where the Roman road has been previously identified
Evaluate potential anomalies in probable and undocumented zones
Compare results with historical records and other archaeological data

tasks.task: Determine the validity of the NDVI methodology for detecting archaeological features
subtasks: Assess the effectiveness of NDVI in recognizing buried structures and linear features
Test the ability of NDVI to differentiate between archaeological remains and natural features

tasks.task: Independently verify findings through ground truthing
subtasks: Cross-reference NDVI results with visual ground surveys
Confirm the presence of features such as ditches, pavement, and structures using excavation or mapping

tasks.task: Conclude on the applicability of NDVI for extensive archaeological reconnaissance
subtasks: Highlight the benefits of NDVI in terms of coverage, non-invasiveness, and efficiency
Compare NDVI success rates with other survey methods and imaging techniques
